**AI Assistant:**
Setting up a larger swap space is a great idea. The reason is that the Verus node only has 1GB of RAM, and a larger swap space can make the system more robust. To set up a 4GB swap space, you can follow these steps:

1. Create a swap file with `sudo fallocate -l 4G /swapfile`.
2. Set permissions to root only with `sudo chmod 600 /swapfile`.
3. Mark the file as swap with `sudo mkswap /swapfile`.
4. Enable the swap file with `sudo swapon /swapfile`.

To make the swap space permanent, you need to edit the `/etc/fstab` file. First, back up the file with `sudo cp /etc/fstab /etc/fstab.bk`. Then, add the swap info to `/etc/fstab` with `echo '/swapfile none swap sw 0 0' | sudo tee -a /etc/fstab`.

Swappiness and Cache Pressure are settings that can be optimized for better performance of your Verus node. Swappiness determines how aggressively the system swaps out memory pages to disk. A lower value means less pressure, which can also be beneficial for servers.

To optimize these settings, you can edit the `/etc/sysctl.conf` file. For Swappiness, you can add `vm.swappiness=40` to the end of the file. For Cache Pressure, you can add `vm.vfs_cache_pressure=50` to the end of the file. Note that these values are examples and may need to be adjusted based on your specific use case.
